metadata.title: How to Prove that a Language Is Regular or Star-Free?

body_text.text: The class of regular languages is the smallest class of languages containing the finite languages that is closed under finite union, finite product and star.
body_text.section: Definition 1 ::: Regular and Star-Free Languages ::: Background

body_text.text: The definition of star-free languages follows the same pattern, with the difference that the star operation is replaced by the complement:
body_text.section: Definition 1 ::: Regular and Star-Free Languages ::: Background

body_text.text: The class of star-free languages is the smallest class of languages containing the finite languages that is closed under finite union, finite product and complement.
body_text.section: Definition 2 ::: Regular and Star-Free Languages ::: Background
Definition 2 ::: Regular and Star-Free Languages ::: Background

body_text.text: Let L be a language. The following conditions are equivalent: L is regular,L is accepted by a finite deterministic automaton,L is accepted by a finite non-deterministic automaton.
body_text.section: Theorem 1 ::: Early Results and Their Consequences ::: Background
Theorem 1 ::: Early Results and Their Consequences ::: Background

body_text.text: Here is another standard result, due to Nerode.
body_text.section: Theorem 1 ::: Early Results and Their Consequences ::: Background

body_text.text: A language is regular if and only if it has finitely many left (respectively right) quotients.
body_text.section: Theorem 2 ::: Early Results and Their Consequences ::: Background
Example 1 ::: Early Results and Their Consequences ::: Background

body_text.text: Let L be a language. The following conditions are equivalent: L is regular,L is recognised by a finite monoid,the syntactic monoid of L is finite.
body_text.section: Proposition 1 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Proposition 1 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Proposition 1 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background

body_text.text: Moreover, the syntactic monoid of a regular language is the transition monoid of its minimal automaton, which gives a convenient algorithm to compute it. It is also the minimal monoid (in size, but also for the division ordering1) that recognises the language.
body_text.section: Proposition 1 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Proposition 1 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background

body_text.text: (Schützenberger [46]). For a language L, the following conditions are equivalent: L is star-free,L is recognised by a finite aperiodic monoid,the syntactic monoid of L a finite aperiodic monoid.
body_text.section: Theorem 3 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background

body_text.text: Schützenberger’s theorem is considered, right after Kleene’s theorem, as the most important result of the algebraic theory of automata.
body_text.section: Theorem 3 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Example 2 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Example 2 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Proposition 2 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Proof ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Proof ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Theorem 4 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Theorem 4 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Proposition 3 ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Proof ::: Recognition by a Monoid and Syntactic Monoid ::: Background
Theorem 5 ::: Pumping ::: Iteration Properties

body_text.text: Stronger versions were proposed by Stanat and Weiss [50] and Ehrenfeucht, Parikh and Rozenberg [15], but the most powerful version was given by Varricchio [54].
body_text.section: Theorem 5 ::: Pumping ::: Iteration Properties
Theorem 6 ::: Pumping ::: Iteration Properties
Definition 3 ::: Periodicity and Permutation ::: Iteration Properties
Definition 3 ::: Periodicity and Permutation ::: Iteration Properties

body_text.text: These definitions were introduced by Restivo and Reutenauer [44], who proved the following result.
body_text.section: Definition 3 ::: Periodicity and Permutation ::: Iteration Properties

body_text.text: A language is regular if and only if it is periodic and permutable.
body_text.section: Proposition 4 ::: Periodicity and Permutation ::: Iteration Properties
Proposition 5 ::: Iteration Properties ::: Iteration Properties

body_text.text: Inverse context-free rewriting systems preserve regularity.
body_text.section: Theorem 7 ::: Rewriting Systems ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders
Proof ::: Rewriting Systems ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders
Proof ::: Rewriting Systems ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders

body_text.text: Suffix (prefix) rewriting systems preserve regularity.
body_text.section: Theorem 8 ::: Suffix Rewriting Systems ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders

body_text.text: Every deleting string rewriting system preserves regularity.
body_text.section: Theorem 9 ::: Deleting Rewriting Systems ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders
Theorem 10 ::: Well Quasi-orders ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders
Theorem 10 ::: Well Quasi-orders ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders

body_text.text: Any rewriting system whose reduction relation is a well quasi-order is a total regulator.
body_text.section: Theorem 11 ::: Well Quasi-orders ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders
Theorem 11 ::: Well Quasi-orders ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders
Theorem 11 ::: Well Quasi-orders ::: Rewriting Systems and Well Quasi-orders

Theorem 18 ::: Logic on Words ::: Logic

body_text.text: The second one relates first order logic and star-free languages.
body_text.section: Theorem 18 ::: Logic on Words ::: Logic
Theorem 19 ::: Logic on Words ::: Logic
Theorem 19 ::: Logic on Words ::: Logic
Theorem 19 ::: Logic on Words ::: Logic
Theorem 19 ::: Logic on Words ::: Logic

body_text.text: For more information on this topic, the reader is invited to read the beautiful survey of Eiter, Gottlob and Schwentick [19].
body_text.section: Theorem 21 ::: Logic on Words ::: Logic
Example 4 ::: Linear Temporal Logic ::: Logic
Example 4 ::: Linear Temporal Logic ::: Logic

body_text.text: A famous result of Kamp [25] states that LTL is equivalent to the first-order logic of order. As a consequence, one gets the following result.
body_text.section: Example 4 ::: Linear Temporal Logic ::: Logic
Theorem 22 ::: Linear Temporal Logic ::: Logic

body_text.text: We just defined future temporal formulas but one can define in the same way past temporal formulas by reversing time: it suffices to replace next by previous, eventually by sometimes and until by since. The expressive power of this extended temporal logic remains the same: it still captures the class of star-free languages.
body_text.section: Theorem 22 ::: Linear Temporal Logic ::: Logic
Theorem 23 ::: Rabin’s Tree Theorem ::: Logic
Theorem 24 ::: Rational and Recognisable Sets ::: Transductions

body_text.text: Furthermore, the following property holds:
body_text.section: Theorem 24 ::: Rational and Recognisable Sets ::: Transductions
Proposition 8 ::: Rational and Recognisable Sets ::: Transductions
Proposition 8 ::: Rational and Recognisable Sets ::: Transductions

body_text.text: Many more examples can be found in [39, 40].
body_text.section: Example 7 ::: Matrix Representations of Transductions ::: Transductions

Proposition 9 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology

body_text.text: Here is an interesting example [41].
body_text.section: Proposition 9 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Proposition 10 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Example 8 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology

Example 8 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology

body_text.text: The following result was proved in [3].
body_text.section: Example 8 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Proposition 11 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology

body_text.text: The class of cyclically ultimately periodic functions has been studied by Siefkes [48], who gave in particular a recursion scheme for producing such functions. The class of residually ultimately periodic sequences was also thoroughly studied in [10, 55] (see also [27, 28, 47]). Their properties are summarized in the next proposition.
body_text.section: Proposition 11 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Theorem 28 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Theorem 28 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Theorem 28 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology

body_text.text: Coming back to regular languages, Seiferas and McNaughton [47] proved the following result.
body_text.section: Theorem 28 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Theorem 29 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Theorem 29 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Theorem 30 ::: Uniformly Continuous Functions and Recognisable sets ::: Profinite Topology
Theorem 31 ::: Transductions and Recognisable Sets ::: Profinite Topology
Theorem 31 ::: Transductions and Recognisable Sets ::: Profinite Topology
Proposition 12 ::: Transductions and Recognisable Sets ::: Profinite Topology
Proposition 13 ::: Transductions and Recognisable Sets ::: Profinite Topology

body_text.text: ([9, Theorem 3.84, p. 185]). The language accepted by a one-tape Turing machine that never writes on its input is regular.
body_text.section: Theorem 32 ::: Further Examples and Conclusion
Theorem 33 ::: Further Examples and Conclusion

body_text.text: The following result is proposed as an exercise in [9, Exercise 4.16, p. 243].
body_text.section: Theorem 33 ::: Further Examples and Conclusion
Theorem 34 ::: Further Examples and Conclusion

body_text.text: Let me also mention a result related to formal power series.
body_text.section: Theorem 34 ::: Further Examples and Conclusion

body_text.text: (Restivo and Reutenauer [44]). If a language and its complement are support of a rational series, then it is a regular language.
body_text.section: Theorem 35 ::: Further Examples and Conclusion

body_text.text: Many other examples could not be included in this survey, notably the work of Bertoni, Mereghetti and Palano [4, Theorem 3, p. 8] on 1-way quantum automata and the large literature on splicing systems.
body_text.section: Theorem 35 ::: Further Examples and Conclusion

body_text.text: I would be very grateful to any reader providing me new interesting examples to enrich this survey.
body_text.section: Theorem 35 ::: Further Examples and Conclusion
